cc @T-infra

I'm curious what counts as a contributor, since I've been helping out with project portable-simd a lot, and am a member, though not really by contributing much code yet. I don't have a hardware security token and would like one, though I'd expect there are better people to give the tokens to.
Likewise. I've contributed some to stdlib and the compiler and would be interested, but it's not like I'm a key person here; I have no "special" permissions such as approving PRs.
If you want but don't get one now, any U2F token will probably work with GitHub and they can be had for $15-$30 in various places. And I think Google doesn't ship them everywhere in the world.

My view here is that many "key persons" are able to bill that on their employer and if we want to encourage token usage, they should lobby their employer. I'd rather use this chance to give that to individuals and not build a ranking. While 15-30 may seem small, keeping away any cost from individual contributors is IMHO a good thing. In the end, finding a rule around this is probably not worth it for 10 items, so liberally giving them away to people expressing interest and maybe providing such an offer more often would be useful.

Also keep in mind it does not matter what you have "social permission" to do, it matters what your account can technically do. Major changes require in RFC, but I have merge permissions on several repository's. If my account were stolen they would not have to make an RFC to do damage. (Personally I got a yubikey as a birthday gift a few years ago, so just using me as an example.) If you say have the ability to close issues, it would still be very disruptive for your compromised account to go around closing all of them.

I'm pretty big on using yubikeys for SSH and OpenPGP for commit signing. It's not _that_ hard to setup and having all my key material safe made things a ton easier for me.

I've had an U2F key for a while, but GitHub lets me enter a password instead, so that's a bit strange. Anyway, my point above is that if you want and can afford one, there's probably no reason to not get a token.

The weird thing about GH is that it expect the second factor on second login, but uses just password for confirmation (e.g. changes and such). (Which, TBH, halfway makes sense - if your screen is unlocked and the key attached and unlocked, you may want to check the pw in all cases).

Note that git itself now supports signing with SSH keys:

https://lore.kernel.org/git/xmqq8rxpgwki.fsf@gitster.g/

In addition to GnuPG, ssh public crypto can be used for object and
push-cert signing. Note that this feature cannot be used with
ssh-keygen from OpenSSH 8.7, whose support for it is broken. Avoid
using it unless you update to OpenSSH 8.8.

I assume github will support that for verified commits in the near future.

A little clarification:

There's a category of tokens generally called "security keys" that just do WebAuthn / U2F. Those are mainly used for web logins. For instance, these are a great way to secure your GitHub account.

As of OpenSSH 8.2 (https://www.openssh.com/txt/release-8.2), a security key _can_ be used for SSH authentication using U2F challenges. Both client and server have be >8.2, and this isn't general purpose key storage, so I believe it can't be used for signing git commits.

The Yubico Security Key Series (https://www.yubico.com/products/) and the Google Titan are both in this category.

Yubico also has the more expensive "YubiKey 5 Series." Those have additional applets on them for GPG and PIV. The PIV applet allows you to generate and store a regular RSA or ECDSA key on the device; you can use it to store a "normal" SSH key on device. If you want to do commit signing I believe you need the 5 Series. I'm not sure from the OP whether the Yubikeys being offered are 5 Series or not. I'm guessing they're Security Keys. Either way, it's a great offer, thank you @John Naulty.

Also I'd definitely encourage anyone who wants one to just go for it; if we exhaust the supply from this offer I'm very happy to help source more. Security keys are awesome!
